import { db } from '@/db';
import { notes } from '@/db/schema';
import { eq } from 'drizzle-orm';

// GET /api/notes/[id] - Retrieve a specific note
export async function GET(
  request: NextRequest,
  { params }: { params: Promise<{ id: string }> }
) {
  try {
    const { id } = await params;
    const noteId = parseInt(id, 10);

    if (isNaN(noteId)) {
      return NextResponse.json({ error: 'Invalid note ID' }, { status: 400 });
    }

    const [note] = await db
      .select()
      .from(notes)
      .where(eq(notes.id, noteId));

    if (!note) {
      return NextResponse.json({ error: 'Note not found' }, { status: 404 });
    }

    return NextResponse.json({ note }, { status: 200 });
  } catch (error) {
    console.error('Error fetching note:', error);
    return NextResponse.json(
      { error: 'Failed to fetch note' },
      { status: 500 }
    );
  }
}

// PATCH /api/notes/[id] - Update a note
export async function PATCH(
  request: NextRequest,
  { params }: { params: Promise<{ id: string }> }
) {
  try {
    const { id } = await params;
    const noteId = parseInt(id, 10);

    if (isNaN(noteId)) {
      return NextResponse.json({ error: 'Invalid note ID' }, { status: 400 });
    }

    const body = await request.json();
    const { title, content } = body;

    // Build update object with only provided fields
    const updateData: { title?: string; content?: string } = {};
    if (title !== undefined) updateData.title = title;
    if (content !== undefined) updateData.content = content;

    if (Object.keys(updateData).length === 0) {
      return NextResponse.json(
        { error: 'No fields to update' },
        { status: 400 }
      );
    }

    const [updatedNote] = await db
      .update(notes)
      .set(updateData)
      .where(eq(notes.id, noteId))
      .returning();

    if (!updatedNote) {
      return NextResponse.json({ error: 'Note not found' }, { status: 404 });
    }

    return NextResponse.json({ note: updatedNote }, { status: 200 });
  } catch (error) {
    console.error('Error updating note:', error);
    return NextResponse.json(
      { error: 'Failed to update note' },
      { status: 500 }
    );
  }
}

// DELETE /api/notes/[id] - Delete a note
export async function DELETE(
  request: NextRequest,
  { params }: { params: Promise<{ id: string }> }
) {
  try {
    const { id } = await params;
    const noteId = parseInt(id, 10);

    if (isNaN(noteId)) {
      return NextResponse.json({ error: 'Invalid note ID' }, { status: 400 });
    }

    const [deletedNote] = await db
      .delete(notes)
      .where(eq(notes.id, noteId))
      .returning();

    if (!deletedNote) {
      return NextResponse.json({ error: 'Note not found' }, { status: 404 });
    }

    return NextResponse.json(
      { message: 'Note deleted successfully', note: deletedNote },
      { status: 200 }
    );
  } catch (error) {
    console.error('Error deleting note:', error);
    return NextResponse.json(
      { error: 'Failed to delete note' },
      { status: 500 }
    );
  }
}

# Neon Drizzle Integration

Comprehensive Drizzle ORM setup for Neon databases with guided workflows.

## When to Use This Skill

- Setting up Drizzle in a new project (Next.js, Vite, Express, etc.)
- Integrating Drizzle into an existing application
- Creating or modifying database schemas
- Troubleshooting migration issues

## Code Generation Rules

When generating TypeScript/JavaScript code:
- BEFORE generating import statements, check tsconfig.json for path aliases (compilerOptions.paths)
- If path aliases exist (e.g., "@/*": ["./src/*"]), use them (e.g., import { x } from '@/lib/utils')
- If NO path aliases exist or unsure, ALWAYS use relative imports (e.g., import { x } from '../../../lib/utils')
- Verify imports match the project's configuration
- Default to relative imports - they always work regardless of configuration

## Available Guides

Each guide is a complete, self-contained walkthrough with numbered phases:

- **`guides/new-project.md`** - Full setup from scratch (see: Table of Contents)
- **`guides/existing-project.md`** - Add Drizzle to running apps (see: Table of Contents)
- **`guides/schema-only.md`** - Schema creation and modification (see: Table of Contents)
- **`guides/troubleshooting.md`** - Debug common issues (organized by error type)

I'll automatically detect your context (package manager, framework, deployment target) and select the appropriate guide based on your request.

## Quick Examples

Tell me what you're building - I'll handle the rest:

- "Setup Drizzle for my Next.js blog on Vercel" → Auto-detects Vercel + Next.js → HTTP adapter
- "Add Drizzle to my Express API" → Auto-detects Node.js server → WebSocket adapter
- "Create a users table with auth fields" → Loads schema guide → Generates schema

## Reference Documentation

For deeper technical details (loaded on-demand):

- `references/adapters.md` - HTTP vs WebSocket decision guide
- `references/migrations.md` - Migration patterns and troubleshooting
- `references/query-patterns.md` - Example queries and best practices

## Templates & Scripts

- `templates/schema-example.ts` - Multi-table schema with relations
- `templates/drizzle-config.ts` - Configuration examples
- `scripts/generate-schema.ts` - Automated migration generation
- `scripts/run-migration.ts` - Programmatic migration runner

## Related Skills

- **neon-serverless** - Connection setup without ORM
- **neon-toolkit** - Ephemeral databases for testing
- **add-neon-docs** - Add Neon best practices to your project (run after setup)

---

## Workflow

I will:
1. Detect your project context automatically
2. Select and load the appropriate guide
3. Follow the guide's phases sequentially
4. Track progress using the guide's workflow checklist
5. Load reference files only when needed
6. Offer to add Neon best practices to your project docs

Ready to get started? Just describe what you're building!

import { db } from '@/db';
import { notes } from '@/db/schema';
import { eq } from 'drizzle-orm';

describe('Notes Integration Tests', () => {
  // Store test note IDs for cleanup
  const testNoteIds: number[] = [];

  afterAll(async () => {
    // Clean up test notes
    if (testNoteIds.length > 0) {
      await db.delete(notes).where(eq(notes.id, testNoteIds[0]));
    }
  });

  it('should add a note to the database and query it back successfully', async () => {
    // Arrange: Prepare test data
    const testNote = {
      title: 'Test Note',
      content: 'This is a test note content',
    };

    // Act: Insert the note
    const insertedNotes = await db
      .insert(notes)
      .values(testNote)
      .returning();

    // Assert: Verify the note was inserted
    expect(insertedNotes).toHaveLength(1);
    const insertedNote = insertedNotes[0];
    expect(insertedNote.id).toBeDefined();
    expect(insertedNote.title).toBe(testNote.title);
    expect(insertedNote.content).toBe(testNote.content);
    expect(insertedNote.createdAt).toBeInstanceOf(Date);
    expect(insertedNote.updatedAt).toBeInstanceOf(Date);

    // Store ID for cleanup
    testNoteIds.push(insertedNote.id);

    // Act: Query the note back from the database
    const queriedNotes = await db
      .select()
      .from(notes)
      .where(eq(notes.id, insertedNote.id));

    // Assert: Verify the queried note matches
    expect(queriedNotes).toHaveLength(1);
    const queriedNote = queriedNotes[0];
    expect(queriedNote.id).toBe(insertedNote.id);
    expect(queriedNote.title).toBe(testNote.title);
    expect(queriedNote.content).toBe(testNote.content);
    expect(queriedNote.createdAt).toEqual(insertedNote.createdAt);
    expect(queriedNote.updatedAt).toEqual(insertedNote.updatedAt);
  });

  it('should insert multiple notes and query them all', async () => {
    // Arrange: Prepare multiple test notes
    const testNotes = [
      { title: 'First Note', content: 'First note content' },
      { title: 'Second Note', content: 'Second note content' },
      { title: 'Third Note', content: 'Third note content' },
    ];

    // Act: Insert multiple notes
    const insertedNotes = await db
      .insert(notes)
      .values(testNotes)
      .returning();

    // Assert: Verify all notes were inserted
    expect(insertedNotes).toHaveLength(3);
    insertedNotes.forEach((note, index) => {
      expect(note.id).toBeDefined();
      expect(note.title).toBe(testNotes[index].title);
      expect(note.content).toBe(testNotes[index].content);
      testNoteIds.push(note.id);
    });

    // Act: Query all inserted notes
    const allNotes = await db.select().from(notes);

    // Assert: Verify we can query them back
    expect(allNotes.length).toBeGreaterThanOrEqual(3);

    // Verify our test notes are in the results
    const insertedIds = insertedNotes.map(n => n.id);
    const queriedTestNotes = allNotes.filter(n => insertedIds.includes(n.id));
    expect(queriedTestNotes).toHaveLength(3);

    // Cleanup
    for (const note of insertedNotes) {
      await db.delete(notes).where(eq(notes.id, note.id));
    }
  });

  it('should update a note successfully', async () => {
    // Arrange: Insert a note
    const initialNote = {
      title: 'Original Title',
      content: 'Original content',
    };

    const [insertedNote] = await db
      .insert(notes)
      .values(initialNote)
      .returning();

    testNoteIds.push(insertedNote.id);

    // Act: Update the note
    const updatedData = {
      title: 'Updated Title',
      content: 'Updated content',
      updatedAt: new Date(),
    };

    const [updatedNote] = await db
      .update(notes)
      .set(updatedData)
      .where(eq(notes.id, insertedNote.id))
      .returning();

    // Assert: Verify the update
    expect(updatedNote.title).toBe(updatedData.title);
    expect(updatedNote.content).toBe(updatedData.content);
    expect(updatedNote.id).toBe(insertedNote.id);

    // Query back to double-check
    const [queriedNote] = await db
      .select()
      .from(notes)
      .where(eq(notes.id, insertedNote.id));

    expect(queriedNote.title).toBe(updatedData.title);
    expect(queriedNote.content).toBe(updatedData.content);

    // Cleanup
    await db.delete(notes).where(eq(notes.id, insertedNote.id));
  });

  it('should delete a note successfully', async () => {
    // Arrange: Insert a note
    const testNote = {
      title: 'Note to Delete',
      content: 'This note will be deleted',
    };

    const [insertedNote] = await db
      .insert(notes)
      .values(testNote)
      .returning();

    // Verify it exists
    const notesBeforeDelete = await db
      .select()
      .from(notes)
      .where(eq(notes.id, insertedNote.id));
    expect(notesBeforeDelete).toHaveLength(1);

    // Act: Delete the note
    await db.delete(notes).where(eq(notes.id, insertedNote.id));

    // Assert: Verify it was deleted
    const notesAfterDelete = await db
      .select()
      .from(notes)
      .where(eq(notes.id, insertedNote.id));
    expect(notesAfterDelete).toHaveLength(0);
  });
});

This directory contains integration tests for the Notes application built with Neon, Drizzle ORM, and Next.js.

## Test Overview

The `notes.integration.test.ts` file contains comprehensive integration tests that verify:

1. **Create and Query**: Adding a note to the database and querying it back successfully
2. **Batch Insert**: Inserting multiple notes and querying them all
3. **Update**: Updating an existing note's content and title
4. **Delete**: Removing a note from the database

## Running the Tests

```bash
npm test
```

## Test Database

The tests use the Neon database configured in `.env.local`. All test data is automatically cleaned up after each test run.

## Database Schema

The notes table has the following structure:

```typescript
{
  id: serial (primary key)
  title: text (not null)
  content: text (not null)
  createdAt: timestamp (default now(), not null)
  updatedAt: timestamp (default now(), not null)
}
```

## Technologies Used

- **Neon**: Serverless Postgres database
- **Drizzle ORM**: Type-safe database operations
- **Vitest**: Fast unit test framework
- **Next.js 16**: React framework with App Router

## Test Results

All 4 tests pass successfully:
- ✓ should add a note to the database and query it back successfully
- ✓ should insert multiple notes and query them all
- ✓ should update a note successfully
- ✓ should delete a note successfully

A full-stack notes application built with Next.js 16, Neon (Serverless Postgres), and Drizzle ORM.

## Tech Stack

- **Next.js 16**: React framework with App Router
- **Neon**: Serverless Postgres database
- **Drizzle ORM**: Type-safe database operations
- **TypeScript**: Type safety throughout the application
- **Vitest**: Fast unit and integration testing

## Database Schema

The application uses a simple notes table:

```typescript
notes {
  id: serial (primary key)
  title: text (not null)
  content: text (not null)
  createdAt: timestamp (default now())
  updatedAt: timestamp (default now())
}
```

## Project Structure

```
├── app/                    # Next.js App Router pages and components
├── db/
│   ├── schema.ts          # Drizzle schema definitions
│   └── index.ts           # Database connection
├── drizzle/               # Generated migrations
├── __tests__/
│   └── notes.integration.test.ts  # Integration tests
├── drizzle.config.ts      # Drizzle configuration
└── .env.local             # Database connection string
```

## Getting Started

First, install dependencies:

```bash
npm install
```

## Database Setup

The database is already configured and migrations have been applied. The connection string is stored in `.env.local`.

### Running Migrations

If you make changes to the schema:

```bash
# Generate migration files
npx drizzle-kit generate

# Apply migrations to the database
npx drizzle-kit migrate
```

## Testing

Run the integration tests:

```bash
npm test
```

The test suite includes:
- ✓ Create and query notes
- ✓ Batch insert multiple notes
- ✓ Update existing notes
- ✓ Delete notes

All tests use the real Neon database and automatically clean up test data.

## Database Operations

Example Drizzle ORM operations:

```typescript
import { db } from '@/db';
import { notes } from '@/db/schema';
import { eq } from 'drizzle-orm';

// Insert a note
const [newNote] = await db
  .insert(notes)
  .values({ title: 'My Note', content: 'Note content' })
  .returning();

// Query all notes
const allNotes = await db.select().from(notes);

// Query by ID
const [note] = await db
  .select()
  .from(notes)
  .where(eq(notes.id, 1));

// Update a note
await db
  .update(notes)
  .set({ title: 'Updated Title' })
  .where(eq(notes.id, 1));

// Delete a note
await db.delete(notes).where(eq(notes.id, 1));
```

## Learn More

- [Next.js Documentation](https://nextjs.org/docs)
- [Drizzle ORM Documentation](https://orm.drizzle.team)
- [Neon Documentation](https://neon.tech/docs)

# Neon Drizzle Integration

Comprehensive Drizzle ORM setup for Neon databases with guided workflows.

## When to Use This Skill

- Setting up Drizzle in a new project (Next.js, Vite, Express, etc.)
- Integrating Drizzle into an existing application
- Creating or modifying database schemas
- Troubleshooting migration issues

## Code Generation Rules

When generating TypeScript/JavaScript code:
- BEFORE generating import statements, check tsconfig.json for path aliases (compilerOptions.paths)
- If path aliases exist (e.g., "@/*": ["./src/*"]), use them (e.g., import { x } from '@/lib/utils')
- If NO path aliases exist or unsure, ALWAYS use relative imports (e.g., import { x } from '../../../lib/utils')
- Verify imports match the project's configuration
- Default to relative imports - they always work regardless of configuration

## Available Guides

Each guide is a complete, self-contained walkthrough with numbered phases:

- **`guides/new-project.md`** - Full setup from scratch (see: Table of Contents)
- **`guides/existing-project.md`** - Add Drizzle to running apps (see: Table of Contents)
- **`guides/schema-only.md`** - Schema creation and modification (see: Table of Contents)
- **`guides/troubleshooting.md`** - Debug common issues (organized by error type)

I'll automatically detect your context (package manager, framework, deployment target) and select the appropriate guide based on your request.

## Quick Examples

Tell me what you're building - I'll handle the rest:

- "Setup Drizzle for my Next.js blog on Vercel" → Auto-detects Vercel + Next.js → HTTP adapter
- "Add Drizzle to my Express API" → Auto-detects Node.js server → WebSocket adapter
- "Create a users table with auth fields" → Loads schema guide → Generates schema

## Reference Documentation

For deeper technical details (loaded on-demand):

- `references/adapters.md` - HTTP vs WebSocket decision guide
- `references/migrations.md` - Migration patterns and troubleshooting
- `references/query-patterns.md` - Example queries and best practices

## Templates & Scripts

- `templates/schema-example.ts` - Multi-table schema with relations
- `templates/drizzle-config.ts` - Configuration examples
- `scripts/generate-schema.ts` - Automated migration generation
- `scripts/run-migration.ts` - Programmatic migration runner

## Related Skills

- **neon-serverless** - Connection setup without ORM
- **neon-toolkit** - Ephemeral databases for testing
- **add-neon-docs** - Add Neon best practices to your project (run after setup)

---

## Workflow

I will:
1. Detect your project context automatically
2. Select and load the appropriate guide
3. Follow the guide's phases sequentially
4. Track progress using the guide's workflow checklist
5. Load reference files only when needed
6. Offer to add Neon best practices to your project docs

Ready to get started? Just describe what you're building!

{ pgTable, serial, text, timestamp } from 'drizzle-orm/pg-core';

export const notes = pgTable('notes', {
  id: serial('id').primaryKey(),
  title: text('title').notNull(),

import { db } from '@/db';
import { notes } from '@/db/schema';
import { eq } from 'drizzle-orm';

describe('Notes Integration Tests', () => {
  // Store IDs of created notes for cleanup
  const createdNoteIds: number[] = [];

  // Clean up after each test
  afterEach(async () => {
    if (createdNoteIds.length > 0) {
      await db.delete(notes).where(eq(notes.id, createdNoteIds[0]));
      createdNoteIds.length = 0;
    }
  });

  it('should add a note to the database and query it back successfully', async () => {
    // Arrange: Create test note data
    const testNote = {
      title: 'Test Note',
      content: 'This is a test note content',
    };

    // Act: Insert the note into the database
    const insertedNotes = await db
      .insert(notes)
      .values(testNote)
      .returning();

    expect(insertedNotes).toHaveLength(1);
    const insertedNote = insertedNotes[0];

    // Store the ID for cleanup
    createdNoteIds.push(insertedNote.id);

    // Assert: Verify the inserted note has correct properties
    expect(insertedNote).toMatchObject({
      title: testNote.title,
      content: testNote.content,
    });
    expect(insertedNote.id).toBeTypeOf('number');
    expect(insertedNote.createdAt).toBeInstanceOf(Date);
    expect(insertedNote.updatedAt).toBeInstanceOf(Date);

    // Act: Query the note back from the database
    const queriedNotes = await db
      .select()
      .from(notes)
      .where(eq(notes.id, insertedNote.id));

    // Assert: Verify we got the note back
    expect(queriedNotes).toHaveLength(1);
    const queriedNote = queriedNotes[0];

    // Assert: Verify the queried note matches what we inserted
    expect(queriedNote).toEqual(insertedNote);
    expect(queriedNote.title).toBe(testNote.title);
    expect(queriedNote.content).toBe(testNote.content);
  });

  it('should query multiple notes', async () => {
    // Arrange: Insert multiple notes
    const testNotes = [
      { title: 'Note 1', content: 'Content 1' },
      { title: 'Note 2', content: 'Content 2' },
      { title: 'Note 3', content: 'Content 3' },
    ];

    const insertedNotes = await db
      .insert(notes)
      .values(testNotes)
      .returning();

    // Store IDs for cleanup
    insertedNotes.forEach((note) => createdNoteIds.push(note.id));

    // Act: Query all notes
    const allNotes = await db.select().from(notes);

    // Assert: Verify we got at least the notes we inserted
    expect(allNotes.length).toBeGreaterThanOrEqual(3);

    // Verify our inserted notes are in the results
    const insertedIds = insertedNotes.map((n) => n.id);
    const foundNotes = allNotes.filter((n) => insertedIds.includes(n.id));
    expect(foundNotes).toHaveLength(3);
  });

  it('should update a note', async () => {
    // Arrange: Insert a note
    const [insertedNote] = await db
      .insert(notes)
      .values({ title: 'Original Title', content: 'Original Content' })
      .returning();

    createdNoteIds.push(insertedNote.id);

    // Act: Update the note
    const updatedTitle = 'Updated Title';
    const [updatedNote] = await db
      .update(notes)
      .set({ title: updatedTitle })
      .where(eq(notes.id, insertedNote.id))
      .returning();

    // Assert: Verify the update
    expect(updatedNote.title).toBe(updatedTitle);
    expect(updatedNote.content).toBe('Original Content');

    // Verify by querying
    const [queriedNote] = await db
      .select()
      .from(notes)
      .where(eq(notes.id, insertedNote.id));

    expect(queriedNote.title).toBe(updatedTitle);
  });

  it('should delete a note', async () => {
    // Arrange: Insert a note
    const [insertedNote] = await db
      .insert(notes)
      .values({ title: 'To Delete', content: 'Delete me' })
      .returning();

    const noteId = insertedNote.id;

    // Act: Delete the note
    await db.delete(notes).where(eq(notes.id, noteId));

    // Assert: Verify the note is deleted
    const queriedNotes = await db
      .select()
      .from(notes)
      .where(eq(notes.id, noteId));

    expect(queriedNotes).toHaveLength(0);
  });
});

  - `createdAt` (timestamp with default)

- **`drizzle.config.ts`**: Drizzle Kit configuration for migrations
- Generated and applied database migrations

### 3. **Integration Tests**

  - ✅ Adding a note to the database and querying it back
  - ✅ Querying multiple notes
  - ✅ Updating a note
  - ✅ Deleting a note
  
All tests include proper cleanup using `afterEach` hooks.

### 4. **Test Configuration**
- Updated `vitest.config.ts` to support path aliases (`@/*`)
- Tests successfully run with `npm test`

## Test Results

# Neon Drizzle Integration

Comprehensive Drizzle ORM setup for Neon databases with guided workflows.

## When to Use This Skill

- Setting up Drizzle in a new project (Next.js, Vite, Express, etc.)
- Integrating Drizzle into an existing application
- Creating or modifying database schemas
- Troubleshooting migration issues

## Code Generation Rules

When generating TypeScript/JavaScript code:
- BEFORE generating import statements, check tsconfig.json for path aliases (compilerOptions.paths)
- If path aliases exist (e.g., "@/*": ["./src/*"]), use them (e.g., import { x } from '@/lib/utils')
- If NO path aliases exist or unsure, ALWAYS use relative imports (e.g., import { x } from '../../../lib/utils')
- Verify imports match the project's configuration
- Default to relative imports - they always work regardless of configuration

## Available Guides

Each guide is a complete, self-contained walkthrough with numbered phases:

- **`guides/new-project.md`** - Full setup from scratch (see: Table of Contents)
- **`guides/existing-project.md`** - Add Drizzle to running apps (see: Table of Contents)
- **`guides/schema-only.md`** - Schema creation and modification (see: Table of Contents)
- **`guides/troubleshooting.md`** - Debug common issues (organized by error type)

I'll automatically detect your context (package manager, framework, deployment target) and select the appropriate guide based on your request.

## Quick Examples

Tell me what you're building - I'll handle the rest:

- "Setup Drizzle for my Next.js blog on Vercel" → Auto-detects Vercel + Next.js → HTTP adapter
- "Add Drizzle to my Express API" → Auto-detects Node.js server → WebSocket adapter
- "Create a users table with auth fields" → Loads schema guide → Generates schema

## Reference Documentation

For deeper technical details (loaded on-demand):

- `references/adapters.md` - HTTP vs WebSocket decision guide
- `references/migrations.md` - Migration patterns and troubleshooting
- `references/query-patterns.md` - Example queries and best practices

## Templates & Scripts

- `templates/schema-example.ts` - Multi-table schema with relations
- `templates/drizzle-config.ts` - Configuration examples
- `scripts/generate-schema.ts` - Automated migration generation
- `scripts/run-migration.ts` - Programmatic migration runner

## Related Skills

- **neon-serverless** - Connection setup without ORM
- **neon-toolkit** - Ephemeral databases for testing
- **add-neon-docs** - Add Neon best practices to your project (run after setup)

---

## Workflow

I will:
1. Detect your project context automatically
2. Select and load the appropriate guide
3. Follow the guide's phases sequentially
4. Track progress using the guide's workflow checklist
5. Load reference files only when needed
6. Offer to add Neon best practices to your project docs

Ready to get started? Just describe what you're building!

import { db } from '@/db';
import { notes } from '@/db/schema';
import { eq } from 'drizzle-orm';

describe('Notes Integration Tests', () => {
  // Store the note ID for cleanup
  let createdNoteId: number;

  afterAll(async () => {
    // Clean up: delete the test note
    if (createdNoteId) {
      await db.delete(notes).where(eq(notes.id, createdNoteId));
    }
  });

  it('should add a note to the database and query it back successfully', async () => {
    // Arrange: Prepare test data
    const testNote = {
      title: 'Test Note',
      content: 'This is a test note content',
    };

    // Act: Insert the note
    const insertResult = await db.insert(notes).values(testNote).returning();

    // Assert: Check insertion
    expect(insertResult).toHaveLength(1);
    expect(insertResult[0]).toMatchObject({
      title: testNote.title,
      content: testNote.content,
    });
    expect(insertResult[0].id).toBeDefined();
    expect(insertResult[0].createdAt).toBeInstanceOf(Date);
    expect(insertResult[0].updatedAt).toBeInstanceOf(Date);

    // Store the created note ID for cleanup
    createdNoteId = insertResult[0].id;

    // Act: Query the note back
    const queriedNotes = await db
      .select()
      .from(notes)
      .where(eq(notes.id, createdNoteId));

    // Assert: Check query result
    expect(queriedNotes).toHaveLength(1);
    expect(queriedNotes[0]).toMatchObject({
      id: createdNoteId,
      title: testNote.title,
      content: testNote.content,
    });
  });

  it('should query all notes from the database', async () => {
    // Arrange: Create multiple test notes
    const testNotes = [
      { title: 'Note 1', content: 'Content 1' },
      { title: 'Note 2', content: 'Content 2' },
    ];

    const insertedNotes = await db.insert(notes).values(testNotes).returning();
    const insertedIds = insertedNotes.map(note => note.id);

    try {
      // Act: Query all notes
      const allNotes = await db.select().from(notes);

      // Assert: Check that our test notes are included
      expect(allNotes.length).toBeGreaterThanOrEqual(2);

      const ourNotes = allNotes.filter(note =>
        insertedIds.includes(note.id)
      );

      expect(ourNotes).toHaveLength(2);
      expect(ourNotes[0].title).toBe('Note 1');
      expect(ourNotes[1].title).toBe('Note 2');
    } finally {
      // Cleanup: Delete test notes
      for (const id of insertedIds) {
        await db.delete(notes).where(eq(notes.id, id));
      }
    }
  });

  it('should update a note in the database', async () => {
    // Arrange: Create a test note
    const [testNote] = await db
      .insert(notes)
      .values({ title: 'Original Title', content: 'Original Content' })
      .returning();

    try {
      // Act: Update the note
      const [updatedNote] = await db
        .update(notes)
        .set({
          title: 'Updated Title',
          content: 'Updated Content',
          updatedAt: new Date(),
        })
        .where(eq(notes.id, testNote.id))
        .returning();

      // Assert: Check update
      expect(updatedNote.title).toBe('Updated Title');
      expect(updatedNote.content).toBe('Updated Content');
      expect(updatedNote.id).toBe(testNote.id);

      // Verify the update persisted
      const [queriedNote] = await db
        .select()
        .from(notes)
        .where(eq(notes.id, testNote.id));

      expect(queriedNote.title).toBe('Updated Title');
      expect(queriedNote.content).toBe('Updated Content');
    } finally {
      // Cleanup
      await db.delete(notes).where(eq(notes.id, testNote.id));
    }
  });

  it('should delete a note from the database', async () => {
    // Arrange: Create a test note
    const [testNote] = await db
      .insert(notes)
      .values({ title: 'To Delete', content: 'Will be deleted' })
      .returning();

    // Act: Delete the note
    await db.delete(notes).where(eq(notes.id, testNote.id));

    // Assert: Verify deletion
    const queriedNotes = await db
      .select()
      .from(notes)
      .where(eq(notes.id, testNote.id));

    expect(queriedNotes).toHaveLength(0);
  });
});

import { db } from '@/db';
import { notes } from '@/db/schema';
import { desc } from 'drizzle-orm';

// GET /api/notes - Get all notes
export async function GET() {
  try {
    const allNotes = await db.select().from(notes).orderBy(desc(notes.createdAt));
    return NextResponse.json(allNotes);
  } catch (error) {
    console.error('Error fetching notes:', error);
    return NextResponse.json(
      { error: 'Failed to fetch notes' },
      { status: 500 }
    );
  }
}

// POST /api/notes - Create a new note
export async function POST(request: NextRequest) {
  try {
    const body = await request.json();
    const { title, content } = body;

    if (!title || !content) {
      return NextResponse.json(
        { error: 'Title and content are required' },
        { status: 400 }
      );
    }

    const [newNote] = await db
      .insert(notes)
      .values({
        title,
        content,
      })
      .returning();

    return NextResponse.json(newNote, { status: 201 });
  } catch (error) {
    console.error('Error creating note:', error);
    return NextResponse.json(
      { error: 'Failed to create note' },
      { status: 500 }
    );
  }
}

import { db } from '@/db';
import { notes } from '@/db/schema';
import { eq } from 'drizzle-orm';

// GET /api/notes/:id - Get a specific note
export async function GET(
  request: NextRequest,
  { params }: { params: Promise<{ id: string }> }
) {
  try {
    const { id } = await params;
    const noteId = parseInt(id);

    if (isNaN(noteId)) {
      return NextResponse.json({ error: 'Invalid note ID' }, { status: 400 });
    }

    const [note] = await db.select().from(notes).where(eq(notes.id, noteId));

    if (!note) {
      return NextResponse.json({ error: 'Note not found' }, { status: 404 });
    }

    return NextResponse.json(note);
  } catch (error) {
    console.error('Error fetching note:', error);
    return NextResponse.json(
      { error: 'Failed to fetch note' },
      { status: 500 }
    );
  }
}

// PUT /api/notes/:id - Update a specific note
export async function PUT(
  request: NextRequest,
  { params }: { params: Promise<{ id: string }> }
) {
  try {
    const { id } = await params;
    const noteId = parseInt(id);

    if (isNaN(noteId)) {
      return NextResponse.json({ error: 'Invalid note ID' }, { status: 400 });
    }

    const body = await request.json();
    const { title, content } = body;

    if (!title && !content) {
      return NextResponse.json(
        { error: 'At least one field (title or content) must be provided' },
        { status: 400 }
      );
    }

    const updateData: any = { updatedAt: new Date() };
    if (title) updateData.title = title;
    if (content) updateData.content = content;

    const [updatedNote] = await db
      .update(notes)
      .set(updateData)
      .where(eq(notes.id, noteId))
      .returning();

    if (!updatedNote) {
      return NextResponse.json({ error: 'Note not found' }, { status: 404 });
    }

    return NextResponse.json(updatedNote);
  } catch (error) {
    console.error('Error updating note:', error);
    return NextResponse.json(
      { error: 'Failed to update note' },
      { status: 500 }
    );
  }
}

// DELETE /api/notes/:id - Delete a specific note
export async function DELETE(
  request: NextRequest,
  { params }: { params: Promise<{ id: string }> }
) {
  try {
    const { id } = await params;
    const noteId = parseInt(id);

    if (isNaN(noteId)) {
      return NextResponse.json({ error: 'Invalid note ID' }, { status: 400 });
    }

    const [deletedNote] = await db
      .delete(notes)
      .where(eq(notes.id, noteId))
      .returning();

    if (!deletedNote) {
      return NextResponse.json({ error: 'Note not found' }, { status: 404 });
    }

    return NextResponse.json({ message: 'Note deleted successfully' });
  } catch (error) {
    console.error('Error deleting note:', error);
    return NextResponse.json(
      { error: 'Failed to delete note' },
      { status: 500 }
    );
  }
}

A full-stack notes application built with Next.js 15+, Drizzle ORM, and Neon PostgreSQL database.

## 🚀 Features

- ✅ Create, read, update, and delete notes
- ✅ PostgreSQL database with Neon serverless
- ✅ Drizzle ORM for type-safe database queries
- ✅ Next.js 15 App Router with API routes
- ✅ Comprehensive integration tests
- ✅ TypeScript support

## 📁 Project Structure

```
.
├── app/
│   └── api/
│       └── notes/
│           ├── route.ts          # GET all notes, POST new note
│           └── [id]/route.ts     # GET, PUT, DELETE specific note
├── db/
│   ├── index.ts                  # Database client setup
│   └── schema.ts                 # Drizzle schema definitions
├── __tests__/
│   └── notes.integration.test.ts # Integration tests
├── drizzle/                      # Generated migrations
├── drizzle.config.ts             # Drizzle configuration
└── .env.local                    # Environment variables
```

## 🗄️ Database Schema

The `notes` table has the following structure:

```typescript
{
  id: serial (primary key)
  title: text (not null)
  content: text (not null)
  createdAt: timestamp (default: now())
  updatedAt: timestamp (default: now())
}
```

## 🔧 Setup

1. **Install dependencies:**
   ```bash
   npm install
   ```

2. **Database connection:**
   The `.env.local` file already contains your Neon database connection string.

3. **Apply database schema:**
   ```bash
   npm run db:push
   ```

## 🧪 Running Tests

Run the integration tests:

```bash
npm test
```

The test suite includes:
- ✅ Adding a note and querying it back
- ✅ Querying all notes
- ✅ Updating a note
- ✅ Deleting a note

## 🛠️ API Endpoints

### Get All Notes
```
GET /api/notes
```

### Create a Note
```
POST /api/notes
Content-Type: application/json

{
  "title": "My Note",
  "content": "Note content here"
}
```

### Get a Specific Note
```
GET /api/notes/:id
```

### Update a Note
```
PUT /api/notes/:id
Content-Type: application/json

{
  "title": "Updated Title",
  "content": "Updated content"
}
```

### Delete a Note
```
DELETE /api/notes/:id
```

## 📝 Available Scripts

- `npm run dev` - Start development server
- `npm run build` - Build for production
- `npm run start` - Start production server
- `npm test` - Run integration tests
- `npm run db:generate` - Generate database migrations
- `npm run db:push` - Push schema changes to database
- `npm run db:studio` - Open Drizzle Studio (database GUI)

## 🔍 Drizzle Studio

Explore your database with Drizzle Studio:

```bash
npm run db:studio
```

This will open a web interface where you can view and manage your database tables.

## 💡 Usage Example

Here's how to use the database client in your code:

```typescript
import { db } from '@/db';
import { notes } from '@/db/schema';
import { eq } from 'drizzle-orm';

// Create a note
const [newNote] = await db.insert(notes)
  .values({ title: 'My Note', content: 'Hello World' })
  .returning();

// Query all notes
const allNotes = await db.select().from(notes);

// Query by ID
const [note] = await db.select()
  .from(notes)
  .where(eq(notes.id, 1));

// Update a note
await db.update(notes)
  .set({ title: 'Updated Title' })
  .where(eq(notes.id, 1));

// Delete a note
await db.delete(notes)
  .where(eq(notes.id, 1));
```

## 🔗 Database Information

- **Project ID:** quiet-sun-11519596
- **Branch:** main
- **Database:** neondb
- **Region:** us-east-1

## 📚 Learn More

- [Neon Documentation](https://neon.tech/docs)
- [Drizzle ORM Documentation](https://orm.drizzle.team)
- [Next.js Documentation](https://nextjs.org/docs)

# Neon Drizzle Integration

Comprehensive Drizzle ORM setup for Neon databases with guided workflows.

## When to Use This Skill

- Setting up Drizzle in a new project (Next.js, Vite, Express, etc.)
- Integrating Drizzle into an existing application
- Creating or modifying database schemas
- Troubleshooting migration issues

## Code Generation Rules

When generating TypeScript/JavaScript code:
- BEFORE generating import statements, check tsconfig.json for path aliases (compilerOptions.paths)
- If path aliases exist (e.g., "@/*": ["./src/*"]), use them (e.g., import { x } from '@/lib/utils')
- If NO path aliases exist or unsure, ALWAYS use relative imports (e.g., import { x } from '../../../lib/utils')
- Verify imports match the project's configuration
- Default to relative imports - they always work regardless of configuration

## Available Guides

Each guide is a complete, self-contained walkthrough with numbered phases:

- **`guides/new-project.md`** - Full setup from scratch (see: Table of Contents)
- **`guides/existing-project.md`** - Add Drizzle to running apps (see: Table of Contents)
- **`guides/schema-only.md`** - Schema creation and modification (see: Table of Contents)
- **`guides/troubleshooting.md`** - Debug common issues (organized by error type)

I'll automatically detect your context (package manager, framework, deployment target) and select the appropriate guide based on your request.

## Quick Examples

Tell me what you're building - I'll handle the rest:

- "Setup Drizzle for my Next.js blog on Vercel" → Auto-detects Vercel + Next.js → HTTP adapter
- "Add Drizzle to my Express API" → Auto-detects Node.js server → WebSocket adapter
- "Create a users table with auth fields" → Loads schema guide → Generates schema

## Reference Documentation

For deeper technical details (loaded on-demand):

- `references/adapters.md` - HTTP vs WebSocket decision guide
- `references/migrations.md` - Migration patterns and troubleshooting
- `references/query-patterns.md` - Example queries and best practices

## Templates & Scripts

- `templates/schema-example.ts` - Multi-table schema with relations
- `templates/drizzle-config.ts` - Configuration examples
- `scripts/generate-schema.ts` - Automated migration generation
- `scripts/run-migration.ts` - Programmatic migration runner

## Related Skills

- **neon-serverless** - Connection setup without ORM
- **neon-toolkit** - Ephemeral databases for testing
- **add-neon-docs** - Add Neon best practices to your project (run after setup)

---

## Workflow

I will:
1. Detect your project context automatically
2. Select and load the appropriate guide
3. Follow the guide's phases sequentially
4. Track progress using the guide's workflow checklist
5. Load reference files only when needed
6. Offer to add Neon best practices to your project docs

Ready to get started? Just describe what you're building!

     2→
     3→> **Complete Walkthrough**: This is a self-contained, step-by-step guide with its own numbered phases (Phase 1-8).
     4→> Follow each phase in order to safely add Drizzle to your existing application.
     5→
     6→Guide for adding Drizzle ORM to an existing application with Neon.
     7→
     8→### Important:
     9→- Remember to run the neon-plugin:add-neon-docs skill with the parameter SKILL_NAME="neon-drizzle" after completing the guide.
    10→
    11→## Table of Contents
    12→
    13→- [Workflow Checklist](#workflow-checklist)
    14→- [Phase 1: Pre-Integration Check](#phase-1-pre-integration-check)
    15→- [Phase 2: Incremental Installation](#phase-2-incremental-installation)
    16→- [Phase 3: Configuration](#phase-3-configuration)
    17→- [Phase 4: Schema Strategy](#phase-4-schema-strategy)
    18→- [Phase 5: Migration Handling](#phase-5-migration-handling)
    19→- [Phase 6: Coexistence Patterns](#phase-6-coexistence-patterns)
    20→- [Phase 7: Verification](#phase-7-verification)
    21→- [Phase 8: Add Best Practices References](#phase-8-add-best-practices-references)
    22→
    23→---
    24→
    25→## Workflow Checklist
    26→
    27→When following this guide, I will track these high-level tasks:
    28→
    29→- [ ] Pre-integration check (detect existing ORMs, database schema, environment)
    30→- [ ] Install Drizzle dependencies without disrupting existing setup
    31→- [ ] Create isolated Drizzle configuration (separate from existing code)
    32→- [ ] Choose and implement schema strategy (new tables vs mirroring existing)
    33→- [ ] Handle migrations safely based on schema strategy
    34→- [ ] Set up coexistence patterns and gradual migration approach
    35→- [ ] Verify Drizzle integration without breaking existing functionality
    36→- [ ] Add Neon Drizzle best practices to project docs
    37→
    38→---
    39→
    40→## Phase 1: Pre-Integration Check
    41→
    42→Before adding Drizzle, check for conflicts:
    43→
    44→### 1.1. Check for Other ORMs
    45→
    46→```bash
    47→grep -E '"(prisma|typeorm|sequelize|mongoose)"' package.json
    48→```
    49→
    50→**If found:**
    51→- Consider migration strategy (coexistence vs replacement)
    52→- Document which tables use which ORM
    53→- Plan gradual migration if needed
    54→
    55→### 1.2. Check Database Schema
    56→
    57→Connect to your database and verify existing tables:
    58→```bash
    59→psql $DATABASE_URL -c "\dt"
    60→```
    61→
    62→**Important:** Note existing tables - Drizzle should not conflict with them.
    63→
    64→### 1.3. Check Environment Setup
    65→
    66→```bash
    67→ls .env .env.local .env.production
    68→grep DATABASE_URL .env*
    69→```
    70→
    71→**If DATABASE_URL exists:**
    72→- Verify connection string format is compatible with Neon (`postgresql://...`)
    73→- If it's a different database provider, you'll need to migrate or provision a Neon database
    74→
    75→**If DATABASE_URL does NOT exist:**
    76→Follow the database provisioning steps from `guides/new-project.md` Phase 3.1:
    77→1. List the projects using the neon MCP Server to check existing projects
    78→2. Create a new project using the neon MCP Server if needed
    79→3. Get the connection string using the neon MCP Server
    80→4. Write to appropriate environment file (.env.local for Next.js, .env for others)
    81→5. Add environment file to .gitignore
    82→
    83→## Phase 2: Incremental Installation
    84→
    85→Add Drizzle without disrupting existing setup:
    86→
    87→### 2.1. Install Dependencies
    88→
    89→**For Vercel/Edge:**
    90→```bash
    91→[package-manager] add drizzle-orm @neondatabase/serverless
    92→[package-manager] add -D drizzle-kit dotenv
    93→```
    94→
    95→**For Node.js:**
    96→```bash
    97→[package-manager] add drizzle-orm @neondatabase/serverless ws
    98→[package-manager] add -D drizzle-kit dotenv @types/ws
    99→```
   100→
   101→### 2.2. Create Isolated Drizzle Directory
   102→
   103→Keep Drizzle separate from existing code:
   104→```bash
   105→mkdir -p src/drizzle
   106→```
   107→
   108→Structure:
   109→```
   110→src/drizzle/
   111→├── index.ts      # Connection
   112→├── schema.ts     # New schemas only
   113→└── migrations/   # Drizzle migrations
   114→```
   115→
   116→## Phase 3: Configuration
   117→
   118→### 3.1. Create Drizzle Config
   119→
   120→Create `drizzle.config.ts` with explicit environment loading:
   121→
   122→**CRITICAL:** The `config({ path: '...' })` must match your environment file name.
   123→
   124→**For Next.js (using .env.local):**
   125→```typescript
   126→import { defineConfig } from 'drizzle-kit';
   127→import { config } from 'dotenv';
   128→
   129→// Load .env.local explicitly
   130→config({ path: '.env.local' });
   131→
   132→export default defineConfig({
   133→  schema: './src/drizzle/schema.ts',
   134→  out: './src/drizzle/migrations',
   135→  dialect: 'postgresql',
   136→  dbCredentials: {
   137→    url: process.env.DATABASE_URL!,
   138→  },
   139→});
   140→```
   141→
   142→**For other projects (using .env):**
   143→```typescript
   144→import { defineConfig } from 'drizzle-kit';
   145→import { config } from 'dotenv';
   146→
   147→// Load .env explicitly
   148→config({ path: '.env' });
   149→
   150→export default defineConfig({
   151→  schema: './src/drizzle/schema.ts',
   152→  out: './src/drizzle/migrations',
   153→  dialect: 'postgresql',
   154→  dbCredentials: {
   155→    url: process.env.DATABASE_URL!,
   156→  },
   157→});
   158→```
   159→
   160→**Notes:**
   161→- Point schema and migrations to `src/drizzle/` to avoid conflicts with existing code
   162→- Explicit dotenv path prevents "url: undefined" errors during migrations
   163→
   164→### 3.2. Create Connection
   165→
   166→`src/drizzle/index.ts` - Choose adapter based on environment (see `references/adapters.md`):
   167→
   168→**HTTP (Vercel/Edge):**
   169→```typescript
   170→import { drizzle } from 'drizzle-orm/neon-http';
   171→import { neon } from '@neondatabase/serverless';
   172→
   173→const sql = neon(process.env.DATABASE_URL!);
   174→export const drizzleDb = drizzle(sql);
   175→```
   176→
   177→**WebSocket (Node.js):**
   178→```typescript
   179→import { drizzle } from 'drizzle-orm/neon-serverless';
   180→import { Pool, neonConfig } from '@neondatabase/serverless';
   181→import ws from 'ws';
   182→
   183→neonConfig.webSocketConstructor = ws;
   184→const pool = new Pool({ connectionString: process.env.DATABASE_URL! });
   185→export const drizzleDb = drizzle(pool);
   186→```
   187→
   188→**Important:** Name export as `drizzleDb` to avoid conflicts with existing `db` exports.
   189→
   190→## Phase 4: Schema Strategy
   191→
   192→Choose integration approach:
   193→
   194→### 4.1. Option A: New Tables Only
   195→
   196→Create schemas for new features only, leave existing tables alone:
   197→
   198→`src/drizzle/schema.ts`:
   199→```typescript
   200→import { pgTable, serial, text, timestamp } from 'drizzle-orm/pg-core';
   201→
   202→export const newFeatureTable = pgTable('new_feature', {
   203→  id: serial('id').primaryKey(),
   204→  data: text('data').notNull(),
   205→  createdAt: timestamp('created_at').defaultNow(),
   206→});
   207→```
   208→
   209→**Pros:**
   210→- No migration of existing data
   211→- Zero risk to current functionality
   212→- Gradual adoption
   213→
   214→**Cons:**
   215→- Mixed query patterns (Drizzle + existing ORM)
   216→- Two connection patterns in codebase
   217→
   218→### 4.2. Option B: Mirror Existing Tables
   219→
   220→Define schemas for existing tables to gradually migrate queries:
   221→
   222→```typescript
   223→import { pgTable, serial, varchar, timestamp } from 'drizzle-orm/pg-core';
   224→
   225→export const existingUsers = pgTable('users', {
   226→  id: serial('id').primaryKey(),
   227→  email: varchar('email', { length: 255 }).notNull(),
   228→  name: varchar('name', { length: 255 }),
   229→  createdAt: timestamp('created_at'),
   230→});
   231→```
   232→
   233→**Pros:**
   234→- Can query existing data with Drizzle
   235→- Gradually replace old ORM queries
   236→- Type-safe access to existing tables
   237→
   238→**Cons:**
   239→- Must match existing schema exactly
   240→- Requires careful migration strategy
   241→
   242→### 4.3. Recommended: Hybrid Approach
   243→
   244→1. Start with Option A (new tables only)
   245→2. Once comfortable, add schemas for frequently-queried existing tables (Option B)
   246→3. Gradually migrate queries from old ORM to Drizzle
   247→4. Eventually remove old ORM
   248→
   249→## Phase 5: Migration Handling
   250→
   251→### 5.1. For New Tables
   252→
   253→Generate and run migrations normally:
   254→```bash
   255→[package-manager] drizzle-kit generate
   256→export DATABASE_URL="$(grep DATABASE_URL .env.local | cut -d '=' -f2)" && \
   257→[package-manager] drizzle-kit migrate
   258→```
   259→
   260→### 5.2. For Existing Tables
   261→
   262→**Do NOT run migrations** - tables already exist!
   263→
   264→Instead, use Drizzle schemas for querying only:
   265→```typescript
   266→import { drizzleDb } from './drizzle';
   267→import { existingUsers } from './drizzle/schema';
   268→
   269→const users = await drizzleDb.select().from(existingUsers);
   270→```
   271→
   272→### 5.3. Mixed Scenario
   273→
   274→If you have both new and existing tables:
   275→1. Define all schemas in `schema.ts`
   276→2. Run `drizzle-kit generate`
   277→3. **Manually edit** generated migration to remove SQL for existing tables
   278→4. Apply migration
   279→
   280→See `references/migrations.md` for advanced patterns.
   281→
   282→### 5.4. Add Migration Scripts
   283→
   284→Add these convenience scripts to your `package.json`:
   285→
   286→```json
   287→{
   288→  "scripts": {
   289→    "db:generate": "drizzle-kit generate",
   290→    "db:migrate": "drizzle-kit migrate",
   291→    "db:push": "drizzle-kit push",
   292→    "db:studio": "drizzle-kit studio"
   293→  }
   294→}
   295→```
   296→
   297→**Usage:**
   298→```bash
   299→npm run db:generate  # Generate migrations from schema changes
   300→npm run db:migrate   # Apply pending migrations
   301→npm run db:push      # Push schema directly (dev only)
   302→npm run db:studio    # Open Drizzle Studio
   303→```
   304→
   305→**Note:** Replace `npm run` with your package manager's equivalent (`pnpm`, `yarn`, `bun`).
   306→
   307→## Phase 6: Coexistence Patterns
   308→
   309→### 6.1. Naming Conventions
   310→
   311→Keep clear separation:
   312→```typescript
   313→import { db as prismaDb } from './lib/prisma';
   314→import { drizzleDb } from './drizzle';
   315→
   316→const prismaUsers = await prismaDb.user.findMany();
   317→const drizzleFeatures = await drizzleDb.select().from(newFeatureTable);
   318→```
   319→
   320→### 6.2. Gradual Migration
   321→
   322→**Step 1:** New features use Drizzle
   323→```typescript
   324→async function createFeature(data: NewFeatureInput) {
   325→  return drizzleDb.insert(newFeatureTable).values(data).returning();
   326→}
   327→```
   328→
   329→**Step 2:** Migrate read queries (safe, no data changes)
   330→```typescript
   331→async function getUsers() {
   332→  return drizzleDb.select().from(existingUsers);
   333→}
   334→```
   335→
   336→**Step 3:** Migrate write queries (after thorough testing)
   337→```typescript
   338→async function updateUser(id: number, data: UserUpdate) {
   339→  return drizzleDb.update(existingUsers)
   340→    .set(data)
   341→    .where(eq(existingUsers.id, id));
   342→}
   343→```
   344→
   345→**Step 4:** Remove old ORM once all queries migrated
   346→
   347→## Phase 7: Verification
   348→
   349→Test integration without breaking existing functionality:
   350→
   351→### 7.1. Test New Tables
   352→
   353→```typescript
   354→import { drizzleDb } from './drizzle';
   355→import { newFeatureTable } from './drizzle/schema';
   356→
   357→const result = await drizzleDb.insert(newFeatureTable)
   358→  .values({ data: 'test' })
   359→  .returning();
   360→
   361→console.log('New table works:', result);
   362→```
   363→
   364→### 7.2. Test Existing Tables (if mirrored)
   365→
   366→```typescript
   367→import { drizzleDb } from './drizzle';
   368→import { existingUsers } from './drizzle/schema';
   369→
   370→const users = await drizzleDb.select().from(existingUsers);
   371→console.log('Existing table accessible:', users);
   372→```
   373→
   374→### 7.3. Verify Old ORM Still Works
   375→
   376→```typescript
   377→import { db as oldDb } from './lib/your-orm';
   378→
   379→const oldQuery = await oldDb.users.findMany();
   380→console.log('Old ORM still works:', oldQuery);
   381→```
   382→
   383→## Phase 8: Add Best Practices References
   384→
   385→Before executing the add-neon-docs skill, provide a summary of everything that has been done:
   386→
   387→"✅ ... Drizzle integration is complete! Now adding documentation references..."
   388→
   389→Then execute the neon-plugin:add-neon-docs skill with the parameter SKILL_NAME="neon-drizzle"
   390→
   391→This will add reference links to Neon + Drizzle best practices documentation in your project's AI documentation file, helping AI assistants provide better guidance in future conversations.
   392→
   393→---
   394→
   395→## ✅ Integration Complete!
   396→
   397→Your Drizzle integration with the existing project is ready to use.
   398→

import { db } from '@/src/drizzle';
import { notes } from '@/src/drizzle/schema';
import { eq } from 'drizzle-orm';

describe('Notes Integration Test', () => {
  let testNoteId: number;

  // Clean up any test data before running tests
  beforeAll(async () => {
    // Delete any existing test notes
    await db.delete(notes).where(eq(notes.title, 'Test Note'));
  });

  // Clean up test data after all tests
  afterAll(async () => {
    if (testNoteId) {
      await db.delete(notes).where(eq(notes.id, testNoteId));
    }
  });

  it('should add a note to the database', async () => {
    // Insert a new note
    const newNote = {
      title: 'Test Note',
      content: 'This is a test note content',
    };

    const result = await db.insert(notes).values(newNote).returning();

    // Verify the insert returned data
    expect(result).toHaveLength(1);
    expect(result[0]).toHaveProperty('id');
    expect(result[0].title).toBe(newNote.title);
    expect(result[0].content).toBe(newNote.content);
    expect(result[0].createdAt).toBeInstanceOf(Date);
    expect(result[0].updatedAt).toBeInstanceOf(Date);

    // Store the ID for cleanup
    testNoteId = result[0].id;
  });

  it('should query the note back from the database', async () => {
    // Query the note we just inserted
    const queriedNotes = await db
      .select()
      .from(notes)
      .where(eq(notes.id, testNoteId));

    // Verify we got the note back
    expect(queriedNotes).toHaveLength(1);
    expect(queriedNotes[0].id).toBe(testNoteId);
    expect(queriedNotes[0].title).toBe('Test Note');
    expect(queriedNotes[0].content).toBe('This is a test note content');
    expect(queriedNotes[0].createdAt).toBeInstanceOf(Date);
    expect(queriedNotes[0].updatedAt).toBeInstanceOf(Date);
  });

  it('should update a note in the database', async () => {
    // Update the note
    const updatedContent = 'This is updated content';
    const updateResult = await db
      .update(notes)
      .set({ content: updatedContent })
      .where(eq(notes.id, testNoteId))
      .returning();

    // Verify the update
    expect(updateResult).toHaveLength(1);
    expect(updateResult[0].content).toBe(updatedContent);

    // Query to confirm the update persisted
    const queriedNotes = await db
      .select()
      .from(notes)
      .where(eq(notes.id, testNoteId));

    expect(queriedNotes[0].content).toBe(updatedContent);
  });

  it('should delete a note from the database', async () => {
    // Delete the note
    const deleteResult = await db
      .delete(notes)
      .where(eq(notes.id, testNoteId))
      .returning();

    // Verify the delete
    expect(deleteResult).toHaveLength(1);
    expect(deleteResult[0].id).toBe(testNoteId);

    // Query to confirm the note was deleted
    const queriedNotes = await db
      .select()
      .from(notes)
      .where(eq(notes.id, testNoteId));

    expect(queriedNotes).toHaveLength(0);

    // Clear testNoteId so afterAll doesn't try to delete again
    testNoteId = 0;
  });

  it('should handle multiple notes', async () => {
    // Insert multiple notes
    const multipleNotes = [
      { title: 'Note 1', content: 'Content 1' },
      { title: 'Note 2', content: 'Content 2' },
      { title: 'Note 3', content: 'Content 3' },
    ];

    const insertResult = await db.insert(notes).values(multipleNotes).returning();

    // Verify all notes were inserted
    expect(insertResult).toHaveLength(3);

    // Query all the notes we just inserted
    const insertedIds = insertResult.map(n => n.id);
    const queriedNotes = await db
      .select()
      .from(notes)
      .where(eq(notes.title, 'Note 1'))
      .limit(3);

    expect(queriedNotes.length).toBeGreaterThanOrEqual(1);

    // Clean up
    for (const id of insertedIds) {
      await db.delete(notes).where(eq(notes.id, id));
    }
  });
});

# Add Neon Knowledge References to Project

This skill adds reference links to Neon documentation and best practices in your project's AI documentation file, enabling AI assistants to quickly access Neon-specific patterns and guidelines without cluttering your project with large documentation files.

## How It Works

This skill follows a simple workflow:

1. **Load metadata** - Read skill information from `skill-knowledge-map.json`
2. **Detect documentation file** - Find `CLAUDE.md`, `AGENTS.md`, or Cursor rules files
3. **Ask permission** - Show what will be added and where
4. **Add references** - Insert URLs in a "Resources & References" section
5. **Report completion** - Confirm successful installation

For detailed workflow steps, see `install-knowledge.md`.

## Parameters

### SKILL_NAME Parameter

Optional. Specifies which skill documentation to install (e.g., `"neon-drizzle"`). If not provided, you'll be prompted to choose from available skills defined in `skill-knowledge-map.json`.

## Usage Examples

**Called from another skill:**
```markdown
Execute the add-neon-docs skill with SKILL_NAME="neon-drizzle"
```

**Called directly by user:**
- "Add neon drizzle knowledge to my project"
- "Install neon serverless documentation"
- "Set up Neon best practices for my AI assistant"

## What Gets Added

References are added to a "Resources & References" section in your AI documentation file:

```markdown
## Resources & References

- **Neon and Drizzle ORM best practices**: https://raw.githubusercontent.com/neondatabase-labs/ai-rules/main/neon-drizzle.mdc
- **Serverless connection patterns**: https://raw.githubusercontent.com/neondatabase-labs/ai-rules/main/neon-serverless.mdc
```

### Target Files (in priority order):
- `CLAUDE.md` - Most common for Claude Code projects
- `AGENTS.md` - Custom AI documentation files
- `.cursor/README.md` or `.cursor/rules.md` - Cursor IDE projects
- Creates `CLAUDE.md` if none exist

### Behavior:
- Existing "Resources & References" sections: New links are appended
- No existing section: Section is created at end of file
- No documentation file: `CLAUDE.md` is created with references

## Related Skills

- **neon-drizzle** - Sets up Drizzle ORM, then offers this skill
- **neon-serverless** - Sets up connections, then offers this skill
- **neon-toolkit** - Sets up ephemeral databases, then offers this skill

## Workflow Reference

For complete implementation details:
- **Workflow**: `install-knowledge.md` - Step-by-step agent workflow with error handling
- **Metadata**: `skill-knowledge-map.json` - Skill definitions and reference URLs

---

## Workflow Implementation

Now I'll execute the installation workflow for you.

**Parameter received**: SKILL_NAME = ${SKILL_NAME || "not provided - will ask user"}

Execute `install-knowledge.md` with the specified SKILL_NAME.

     2→
     3→**When to use**: When the user wants to add Neon's best practices reference links to their project's AI documentation.
     4→
     5→**Required parameter**: `SKILL_NAME` (e.g., "neon-drizzle", "neon-serverless", "neon-toolkit")
     6→
     7→---
     8→
     9→> **IMPORTANT - Working Directory Context**
    10→>
    11→> This skill reads metadata from its own skill directory (`skill-knowledge-map.json`), but **ALL project file operations** (reading/writing `CLAUDE.md`, `AGENTS.md`, etc.) **MUST happen in the current working directory**.
    12→>
    13→> - ✅ Read skill metadata from skill directory (absolute paths provided by system)
    14→> - ✅ Read/write project files using **relative paths only** (e.g., `CLAUDE.md`, `.cursor/rules.md`)
    15→> - ❌ Never construct project file paths using absolute paths or the skill's base directory
    16→
    17→---
    18→
    19→## Step 1: Load Skill Metadata
    20→
    21→Read the skill metadata file to get the reference URLs.
    22→
    23→The metadata file is bundled with this skill at:
    24→```
    25→skill-knowledge-map.json
    26→```
    27→
    28→Use the Read tool to read the local file, then parse the JSON content.
    29→
    30→Extract the metadata for the current `SKILL_NAME` from the JSON.
    31→
    32→Store this information - you'll need:
    33→- `displayName`: Human-readable skill name
    34→- `files`: Array of .mdc files (each with `url`, `filename`, `description`)
    35→
    36→If the skill is not found in metadata, inform the user and exit.
    37→
    38→---
    39→
    40→## Step 2: Detect AI Documentation File
    41→
    42→Use your existing tools to detect where to add the reference links in the **current working directory**. **This is a read-only check - no files are created yet.**
    43→
    44→Check in this priority order:
    45→
    46→### 2.1 Check for CLAUDE.md (most common)
    47→
    48→Use the Glob tool to search for `CLAUDE.md` in the current working directory:
    49→```
    50→pattern: "CLAUDE.md"
    51→```
    52→
    53→**If found**: Target is `CLAUDE.md` file
    54→
    55→### 2.2 Check for AGENTS.md (custom AI docs)
    56→
    57→Use the Glob tool to search for `AGENTS.md`:
    58→```
    59→pattern: "AGENTS.md"
    60→```
    61→
    62→**If found**: Target is `AGENTS.md` file
    63→
    64→### 2.3 Check for Cursor rules file
    65→
    66→Use the Glob tool to search for Cursor rules files:
    67→```
    68→pattern: ".cursor/README.md"
    69→pattern: ".cursor/rules.md"
    70→```
    71→
    72→**If found**: Target is `.cursor/README.md` or `.cursor/rules.md`
    73→
    74→### 2.4 No file found
    75→If none of the above exist, set target as: "Will create `CLAUDE.md`"
    76→
    77→**Store the detection result** for use in Step 3.
    78→
    79→---
    80→
    81→## Step 3: Present Plan and STOP for User Confirmation
    82→
    83→**STOP HERE.** Do not proceed to Step 4 until the user explicitly confirms.
    84→
    85→Now that you know WHAT to add (from Step 1) and WHERE to add it (from Step 2), present this plan to the user in natural language:
    86→
    87→---
    88→
    89→I've prepared to add **${displayName}** best practices references to your project.
    90→
    91→**Target location:** ${detected_location or "Will create CLAUDE.md"}
    92→
    93→**References to add:**
    94→${list each file with a bullet point showing the description and URL}
    95→
    96→This helps your AI assistant reference Neon best practices automatically in future conversations without cluttering your project with large documentation files.
    97→
    98→Would you like me to proceed with adding these references?
    99→
   100→---
   101→
   102→**Wait for explicit user confirmation** (e.g., "yes", "go ahead", "proceed") before continuing to Step 4.
   103→
   104→If the user declines or asks to skip, thank them and exit the workflow gracefully.
   105→
   106→---
   107→
   108→## Step 4: Add Reference Links
   109→
   110→### 4.1 Build the reference content
   111→
   112→For each file in the metadata, create a reference line:
   113→
   114→```markdown
   115→- **${description}**: ${url}
   116→```
   117→
   118→Combine all references into a section:
   119→
   120→```markdown
   121→## Resources & References
   122→
   123→- **${file1.description}**: ${file1.url}
   124→- **${file2.description}**: ${file2.url}
   125→```
   126→
   127→### 4.2 Check if "Resources & References" section exists
   128→
   129→Read the target file and check if it already has a "## Resources & References" section.
   130→
   131→**If section exists:**
   132→- Use the Edit tool to append new references to that section
   133→- Add the new links after existing content in that section
   134→- Ensure proper spacing (blank line between entries)
   135→
   136→**If section doesn't exist:**
   137→- Append the entire section to the end of the file
   138→- Add two blank lines before the section for proper spacing
   139→
   140→**If target file doesn't exist yet:**
   141→- Use the Write tool to create a new file with:
   142→  ```markdown
   143→  # Project AI Documentation
   144→
   145→  ## Resources & References
   146→
   147→  - **${file.description}**: ${file.url}
   148→  ```
   149→
   150→### 4.3 Perform the edit/write
   151→
   152→**IMPORTANT**: Use relative paths only when calling Write/Edit tools.
   153→
   154→Examples:
   155→- ✅ Correct: `file_path: "CLAUDE.md"`
   156→- ✅ Correct: `file_path: ".cursor/rules.md"`
   157→- ❌ Wrong: `file_path: "/absolute/path/to/CLAUDE.md"`
   158→
   159→Execute the appropriate tool operation based on the above conditions.
   160→
   161→### 4.4 Confirm installation
   162→
   163→Log: `✓ Added ${displayName} reference links to ${target_location}`
   164→
   165→---
   166→
   167→## Step 5: Report Completion
   168→
   169→Build a completion message:
   170→
   171→```markdown
   172→✅ Reference links added successfully!
   173→
   174→Location: ${target_location}
   175→
   176→References added:
   177→${list each reference with title and URL}
   178→
   179→---
   180→
   181→Your AI assistant can now reference these Neon best practices in future conversations by following the URLs. The documentation includes:
   182→- Connection patterns and configuration
   183→- Best practices and gotchas
   184→- Code examples and templates
   185→- Common patterns and solutions
   186→
   187→${if target is CLAUDE.md:}
   188→Note: I'll automatically reference these resources when you ask about ${SKILL_NAME} topics.
   189→${end if}
   190→
   191→${if target is Cursor:}
   192→Note: Cursor can access these resources when working on related code.
   193→${end if}
   194→```
   195→
   196→---
   197→
   198→## Error Handling
   199→
   200→### If metadata file cannot be read
   201→- Log a clear error message
   202→- Suggest checking internet connection
   203→- Exit workflow
   204→
   205→### If write permissions denied
   206→- Inform user about permission issue
   207→- Suggest running with appropriate permissions
   208→- Provide manual instructions for adding links
   209→
   210→### If target file is locked or unavailable
   211→- Inform user of the issue
   212→- Suggest closing editors or checking file permissions
   213→- Provide the reference links for manual addition
   214→
   215→---
   216→
   217→## Testing This Workflow
   218→
   219→As Claude, you can test this workflow by:
   220→
   221→1. Reading the metadata file
   222→2. Detecting the current project's documentation file
   223→3. Simulating user responses (or asking real questions)
   224→4. Adding references to test locations
   225→
   226→Verify:
   227→- [ ] Metadata loads correctly
   228→- [ ] File detection works for multiple project types
   229→- [ ] Permission prompt is clear
   230→- [ ] References are added in the correct format
   231→- [ ] Existing "Resources & References" sections are preserved
   232→- [ ] New sections are created when needed
   233→- [ ] Error messages are clear
   234→
   235→---
   236→

   238→

   240→

Comprehensive Drizzle ORM setup for Neon databases with guided workflows.

## When to Use This Skill

- Setting up Drizzle in a new project (Next.js, Vite, Express, etc.)
- Integrating Drizzle into an existing application
- Creating or modifying database schemas
- Troubleshooting migration issues

## Code Generation Rules

When generating TypeScript/JavaScript code:
- BEFORE generating import statements, check tsconfig.json for path aliases (compilerOptions.paths)
- If path aliases exist (e.g., "@/*": ["./src/*"]), use them (e.g., import { x } from '@/lib/utils')
- If NO path aliases exist or unsure, ALWAYS use relative imports (e.g., import { x } from '../../../lib/utils')
- Verify imports match the project's configuration
- Default to relative imports - they always work regardless of configuration

## Available Guides

Each guide is a complete, self-contained walkthrough with numbered phases:

- **`guides/new-project.md`** - Full setup from scratch (see: Table of Contents)
- **`guides/existing-project.md`** - Add Drizzle to running apps (see: Table of Contents)
- **`guides/schema-only.md`** - Schema creation and modification (see: Table of Contents)
- **`guides/troubleshooting.md`** - Debug common issues (organized by error type)

I'll automatically detect your context (package manager, framework, deployment target) and select the appropriate guide based on your request.

## Quick Examples

Tell me what you're building - I'll handle the rest:

- "Setup Drizzle for my Next.js blog on Vercel" → Auto-detects Vercel + Next.js → HTTP adapter
- "Add Drizzle to my Express API" → Auto-detects Node.js server → WebSocket adapter
- "Create a users table with auth fields" → Loads schema guide → Generates schema

## Reference Documentation

For deeper technical details (loaded on-demand):

- `references/adapters.md` - HTTP vs WebSocket decision guide
- `references/migrations.md` - Migration patterns and troubleshooting
- `references/query-patterns.md` - Example queries and best practices

## Templates & Scripts

- `templates/schema-example.ts` - Multi-table schema with relations
- `templates/drizzle-config.ts` - Configuration examples
- `scripts/generate-schema.ts` - Automated migration generation
- `scripts/run-migration.ts` - Programmatic migration runner

## Related Skills

- **neon-serverless** - Connection setup without ORM
- **neon-toolkit** - Ephemeral databases for testing
- **add-neon-docs** - Add Neon best practices to your project (run after setup)

---

## Workflow

I will:
1. Detect your project context automatically
2. Select and load the appropriate guide
3. Follow the guide's phases sequentially
4. Track progress using the guide's workflow checklist
5. Load reference files only when needed
6. Offer to add Neon best practices to your project docs

Ready to get started? Just describe what you're building!

import { eq } from 'drizzle-orm';
import { db } from '@/db';
import { notes, type NewNote } from '@/db/schema';
import * as dotenv from 'dotenv';

// Load environment variables
dotenv.config({ path: '.env.local' });

describe('Notes Integration Tests', () => {
  let testNoteId: number;

  beforeAll(async () => {
    // Clean up any existing test notes
    await db.delete(notes);
  });

  afterAll(async () => {
    // Clean up test data after all tests
    await db.delete(notes);
  });

  it('should add a note to the database', async () => {
    const newNote: NewNote = {
      title: 'Test Note',
      content: 'This is a test note content',
    };

    const [insertedNote] = await db.insert(notes).values(newNote).returning();

    expect(insertedNote).toBeDefined();
    expect(insertedNote.id).toBeDefined();
    expect(insertedNote.title).toBe('Test Note');
    expect(insertedNote.content).toBe('This is a test note content');
    expect(insertedNote.createdAt).toBeInstanceOf(Date);
    expect(insertedNote.updatedAt).toBeInstanceOf(Date);

    // Store the ID for the next test
    testNoteId = insertedNote.id;
  });

  it('should query the note back from the database', async () => {
    const queriedNotes = await db.select().from(notes);

    expect(queriedNotes).toHaveLength(1);
    expect(queriedNotes[0].id).toBe(testNoteId);
    expect(queriedNotes[0].title).toBe('Test Note');
    expect(queriedNotes[0].content).toBe('This is a test note content');
  });

  it('should query a specific note by id', async () => {
    const [queriedNote] = await db
      .select()
      .from(notes)
      .where(eq(notes.id, testNoteId));

    expect(queriedNote).toBeDefined();
    expect(queriedNote.id).toBe(testNoteId);
    expect(queriedNote.title).toBe('Test Note');
    expect(queriedNote.content).toBe('This is a test note content');
  });

  it('should add multiple notes and query them all', async () => {
    const newNotes: NewNote[] = [
      { title: 'Second Note', content: 'Content of second note' },
      { title: 'Third Note', content: 'Content of third note' },
    ];

    await db.insert(notes).values(newNotes);

    const allNotes = await db.select().from(notes);

    expect(allNotes.map(n => n.title)).toContain('Second Note');
    expect(allNotes.map(n => n.title)).toContain('Third Note');
  });

  it('should update a note', async () => {
    const [updatedNote] = await db
      .update(notes)
      .set({
        title: 'Updated Test Note',
        content: 'This content has been updated'
      })
      .where(eq(notes.id, testNoteId))
      .returning();

    expect(updatedNote.title).toBe('Updated Test Note');
    expect(updatedNote.content).toBe('This content has been updated');
  });

  it('should delete a note', async () => {
    await db.delete(notes).where(eq(notes.id, testNoteId));

    const remainingNotes = await db.select().from(notes);
    expect(remainingNotes).toHaveLength(2);
    expect(remainingNotes.find(n => n.id === testNoteId)).toBeUndefined();
  });
});
